memo: <strong>This plant is weedy. We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> This species is a large shrub or small tree that is popular as a street tree in parts of its native range in southern Mexico, throughout Central America, to northern South America. In Central America its wood is used for everything from fence posts to furniture and its fragrant flowers are a source of nectar for bees. It has leathery leaves, as opposed to the more membranous leaves of <em>C. spinosum</em>.&nbsp; It is naturalized and spreading throughout the windward sides of several Hawaiian Islands, as birds are attracted to the small fruits. <em>Citharexylum caudatum</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 15 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: Native to the Caribbean and Central America. Planted throughout the neotropics and Pacific as an ornamental tree. (Little, 1989)
photolocations: University of Hawaii - Hilo, HI

memo: Fiddlewood is a popular shade and street tree around Honolulu and other urban areas throughout Hawaiâ€˜i. It thrives in many conditions but seems to do best in drier areas as street trees in leeward areas. The species is dioecious (separate male and female individuals) and only males should be planted so the fruit on females are not dispersed into native forests by birds. The fruit can also be messy. The fruit can be eaten raw, twigs and bark are medicinal, and the wood can be used to make furniture. <em>Citharexylum spinosum</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 7 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: The essential oil from small tree used in traditional medicine and aroma therapy in Thailand. (Mar & Pripdeevech, 2014)
photolocations: Pinceville, Hilo and Oahu, HI
native_range: Northern South America and Lesser Antilles
flower_type: Has male and female reproductive parts in each flower (perfect)

memo: This species is native to Hawaiian dryland forests, and should be planted more frequently as an ornamental tree, especially on leeward areas of Hawaiâ€˜i. It flowers during the summer while leafless, when its beautiful, swollen trunk and striking orange bark are most visible. Lightweight wiliwili wood was traditionally used to make canoe outriggers, fishing floats, and surfboards, and seeds are esteemed for leis. Unfortunately, beginning in 2005, the wiliwili has been seriously impacted by the erythrina gall wasp (<em>Quadrastichus erythrinae</em>), which attacks and curls the leaves. A serious enough infestation can lead to death of the tree.&nbsp;<em>Erythrina</em><em>&nbsp;sandwicensis</em>&nbsp;has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score.
ethnobotanical_info: HawaiÊ»iâ€™s endemic coral tree is called the wiliwili, and has both utilitarian and cultural value in the islands. The buoyant, lightweight, wood was used to make traditional surfboards and an element of <i>waÊ»a</i><i> </i>(outrigger canoe) construction. The hard bright-red seeds are pierced and strung together to make lei. In the <i>kumulipo</i> (Hawaiian creation chant), the wiliwili tree is born from <i>pÅ</i> (darkness, the first night) along with other culturally significant native plants and animals.
photolocations: Koko Crater Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI

memo: Banyan trees are far too large for home gardens. It is a shade tree for public parks, estates, churchyards, schools, and other spacious areas. It is salt tolerant and can be grown near the ocean in sandy beach soil, fully exposed to windblown salt spray. Unfortunately scale insects often infest the foliage, leading to unsightly growths of sooty mold fungus, which thrives on the insect exrement.Fruit can be eaten raw. The leaves are used to remedy dysentery and diarrhoea. The aerial roots are used for temporary binding materials. The bark and leaves contain tannins. The latex obtained from all parts of the plant can be used to produce an inferior quality rubber.&nbsp;<em>Ficus benghalensis</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 3 (Evaluate).&nbsp;&nbsp;
ethnobotanical_info: This banyan species is considered sacred to both Hindu and Buddhist religions, where it is planted around temples and places of worship. <i>F. </i><i>benghalensis</i><i> </i>is the national tree of India. It is widely used in Ayurveda traditional medicine, and has proven to contain anti-oxidants, anti-tumor, ant-diarrhea, and would healing properties. The treeâ€™s canopy can attain enormous proportions, with particularly large specimens reaching 19,000 square meters. (Gopukumar & Praseetha, 2015)
photolocations: Oahu, Kona, Maui, HI

alternative_common_names: HAU,COASTAL HIBISCUS,COTTONWOOD,SEA HIBISCUS,BEACH HIBISCUS,COASTAL COTTONWOOD,GREEN COTTONWOOD,NATIVE ROSELLA,KURRAJONG,SEA ROSEMALLOW,MARI,PAGO,LO,FAU,PAGU,LAW,LOO,ARAMAL,CHERAMALL,CHERNALL,EMALL,KARAMAL,XIRIFOI,ISOU,HETAU,ITUU,RAKICH,WEENGU,REKICH,GAAL,GILIGA,KILIFU,GILIVO,SAPWO,KELEU,HULIFUI
memo: This Hawaiian indigenous species thrives in wet habitats, in brackish swamps, or freshwater courses inland. It is planted for shade in coastal areas exposed to salt spray and strong winds or used as a privacy screen, windbreak, or hedge. Variegated varieties are commonly grown. The wood is used for boat construction, firewood, and carvings. The bark and roots may be boiled to make a cooling tea. Hau inner bark has numerous uses for rope, coarse nets, medicine, fire-making, canoe booms and floats, and lei cordage.&nbsp;<em>Hibiscus tiliaceus</em> has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score.
ethnobotanical_info: This species of Hibiscus is known as <i>hau</i><i> </i>in HawaiÊ»i, and is culturally important throughout Polynesia. Hau was one of the 36 Ê»canoe plantsâ€™ introduced to Hawaiâ€™i by Pacific voyagers for their utilitarian necessity and cultural value. The inner bark is prepared and plaited in Samoa to make â€˜<i>ie</i><i> </i><i>sina</i>, which are heavy skirts worn by women during ceremonial dances. Throughout the Pacific, hau is an important cordage plant; the inner bark is braided or twisted to make strong rope, cord, nets, sandals, and baskets. The â€˜<i>ama</i> (outrigger float) of <i>waÊ»a</i> (canoes) were made with the buoyant wood of hau, as well as fishing floats and lures. In Fiji and Samoa, the inner fiber are used to strain and prepare <i>kava</i>.  The traditional medicinal uses of hau include lubricant for childbirth, laxative, treating ulcers, and healing bone fractures. The flowers are also used throughout the Pacific for adornment, ritual ornamentation, and lei creation. (Abbott, 1992; Elevitch & Thomson, 2006; Whistler, 2000)
photolocations: Oahu, Hilo, HI
landscape_application: Seaside Tree,Coastal Screen,Shade Tree,Coastal Street Tree

alternative_common_names: FALSE DOA,JUMBAY,WHITE LEADTREE,WHITE POPINAC,RIVER TAMARIND,TANGAN-TANGAN,IPIL-IPIL,LAMTORO,FUAPEPE,LUSINA,TALNTANGAN,TANGAN TANGAN,TANGAN,TANGUTANG,TELENGTUNGD,TELENTUND,DANGANDANGAN,ROHBOHTIN,TUHNGANTUHNGAN,GANITNITYUWAN,TANTANGAN,WHITE LEAD TREE
memo: <strong>This plant is weedy. We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> Haole koa is the most abundant naturalized tree in low elevation areas of the Hawaiian Islands. It was once used to regenerate barren, eroded lands, but grew too well and spread over large areas, outcompeting native vegetation. The wood can be used for fire and charcoal and the plant is eaten by cattle and goats, but can be toxic at high levels, especially for horses.&nbsp;<em>Leucaena</em><em>&nbsp;leucocephala</em>&nbsp;has a&nbsp;HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 15&nbsp;(High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: This species was originally native to coastal Mexico, but has since naturalized extensively throughout the tropics. An extremely valuable forage legume because it is highly nutritious for ruminants; the foliage contains the highest forage protein quantities among tropical legumes. This species is widely planted in agroforestry systems, companion cropping, and ruminant rangeland. Commonly called â€˜<i>haole </i><i>koa</i><i>â€™</i> in HawaiÊ»i, meaning foreign or breath-less koa, for its invasive nature and resemblance to native <i>Acacia </i><i>koa</i> at the seedling stage. (Garcia et al., 1996; Shelton & Brewbaker, 1994)
photolocations: UC Riverside Botanical Garden - Riverside, CA and Kona and Oahu HI

memo: Ohia&nbsp;is a culturally important, endemic Hawaiian tree that dominates native forests, and is the most abundant native tree, especially on the Big Island and Kauai. It occupies a variety of habitats and grows from a tall emergent rainforest tree to a short, prostrate shrub. It has leathery leaves that are often felty white on the undersides, and rough trunk covered in flaky, fissured bark. Their bright red flowers are laced with nectar and are an important food source for native Hawaiian birds. A fungal disease called rapid hia death&nbsp;has been found on&nbsp;Hawaiâ€˜i, Kauai, Maui, and Oahu (https://cms.ctahr.hawaii.edu/rod/). The disease is comprised of two pathogens,&nbsp;<em>Ceratocystis lukuohia and Ceratocystis huliohia</em>.&nbsp;<em>Metrosideros polymorpha</em> has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score, and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/metrosideros-polymorpha/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/metrosideros-polymorpha/</a>
ethnobotanical_info: â€˜ÅŒhiÊ»a lehua is endemic to the Hawaiian Islands, where it is critical to the ecology, culture, and worldview of the place and people. â€˜ÅŒhiÊ»a is the dominant canopy tree in native forests, and is a vital element to the hydrology, species interactions, and habitat structure of the Hawaiian forest. â€˜ÅŒhiÊ»a is featured in numerous <i>Ê»</i><i>olelo</i><i> </i><i>no</i><i>Ê»</i><i>eau</i> (wise sayings), <i>oli</i> (chants), and<i> </i><i>moÊ»olelo</i><i> </i>(story, myths).  Intricate <i>kiÊ»i</i> (sacred images of gods in sculpture) were carved from Ê»ÅhiÊ»a wood and placed around <i>heiau</i> (temples). Ê»ÅŒhiÊ»a is the <i>kinolau</i> (natural and transformational embodiment of gods) of the gods KÅ«, KÄne, and is sacred to the goddesses Pele and Laka. The wood is also used in utilitarian purposes for house construction, <i>waÊ»a</i> (canoes), firewood,  fencing, <i>Ê»umeke</i> (carved calabash bowls), tools, adornments, and musical instruments.  Traditional lei incorporate the <i>liko</i><i> lehua</i> (buds), <i>lehua</i> (flowers), and <i>lau</i> (foliage) of Ê»ÅhiÊ»a lehua, to be worn for ceremonial hula or everyday use. The flowers are used in <i>laÊ»au</i><i> </i><i>lapaÊ»au</i> (Hawaiian traditional medicine) to ease the pain of childbirth. (Abbott, 1992; Friday & Herbert, 2006; B. H. Krauss, 2001; Pukui & Varez, 1983)
photolocations: Oahu, HI

memo: This culturally significant, wind and salt tolerant, small tree is native to many Pacific islands, including Hawaiâ€˜i. It makes large aerial stilt roots and spirals of spiny leaves 3-ft. -long at the end of thick branches. The fruit on female trees resembles a pineapple. The fruit can be eaten once cooked, and the aerial roots yield a decoction that is used medicinally. The long, narrow, sharp-pointed leaves (lau hala) are weaved into hats, mats, baskets, clothing, sails etc.&nbsp;<em>Pandanus tectorius</em>&nbsp;has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score, and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pandanus-tectorius/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pandanus-tectorius/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: <i>Pandan</i><i>u</i><i>s </i><i>tectorius</i> is important throughout Pacific Island cultures for weaving mats and other essential household goods. <i>Hala</i> was transported as a canoe plant throughout Oceania. <i>Lauhala</i> refers to the leaves of Pandanus, while <i>hala</i> refers to the tree itself. In HawaiÊ»i, native <i>hala</i> populations predated human settlement based on paleo-botanical evidence, and new varieties were also brought by Tahitian peoples. Leaves are collected, soaked in water, dried, marginal spines are removed, and softened with a roller to prepare for plaiting. Mats, baskets, hats, jewelry, sails, thatching, and other adornments are made throughout the Pacific, with regionally specific styles. The keys of <i>P. </i><i>tectorius</i> fruit are commonly used as paintbrushes to decorate <i>kapa</i> (barkcloth). Sacred groves of hala are cultivated and stewarded by local people throughout the Pacific. (Abbott, 1992; MacDowell et al., 2014; Whistler, 2000)
photolocations: Hilo, Maui and Oahu, HI

memo: <strong>This plant is weedy. We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> This tree, which is native to coastal South America, is naturalized in a number of places throughout the world, including Hawaiâ€˜i. In Hawaiâ€˜i, gardeners and foresters no longer plant it, yet it is common in coastal areas on the dry leeward sides of all the major islands. All the individuals in Hawaiâ€˜i are said to descend from one tree, which was planted in front of the Catholic Mission in downtown Honolulu in 1828. Kiawe s hard wood makes excellent charcoal and the flowers are a source of nectar for honey.&nbsp;<em>Prosopis pallida</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 20 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: Mesquite is native to South America, where it is called <i>huarango</i><i> </i>or <i>algarrobo</i>. Mesquite are important trees to human societies worldwide for nutrition, economic, agriculture, and medicine, but are simultaneously highly invasive in grasslands and dry forest ecosystems.  <i>P. pallida</i> was introduced to HawaiÊ»i in 1828, and subsequently given the Hawaiian name Ê»kiaweâ€™. Kiawe was one of the only shade trees in urban Honolulu throughout the 1800â€™s. Kiawe flowers are an important nectar source for bees in HawaiÊ»i, and the white kiawe honey is commercially produced across the islands. With its sweet distinctive fragrance when burned, kiawe is the choice wood in HawaiÊ»i to roast and smoke meat. Walking in slippers underneath kiawe trees can be perilous due to their large thorns. (Little, 1989; Pasiecznik et al., 2001; Shackleton et al., 2014)
photolocations: Kona and Oahu, HI

memo: Many of the twenty-eight species of <em>Ptychosperma</em> readily hybridize, making their identification difficult. This species is usually clustering and branched from the ground, whereas the solitaire palm (<em>P. elegans</em>) has a solitary trunk. This is the most commonly grown <em>Ptychosperma</em> in Hawaiâ€˜i. It grows well in full sun, with plenty of water and well-drained, rich soil. The fruit flesh can cause skin irritation, and the apical buds of some species are eaten, like palm hearts, in their native range. <em>Ptychosperma macarthurii</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 1 (Evaluate).
ethnobotanical_info: An ornamental palm native to the understory of the Australiaâ€™s wet northeastern forests. It has been introduced and naturalized in Central America, where its degree of invasiveness remains unclear.
photolocations: University of Miami - Miami, FL, Foster Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI and Lyon Arboretum - Honolulu, HI
flower_type: Has male and female reproductive parts in each flower (perfect)

alternative_common_names: PALMISTE,IMPERIAL PALM,CABBAGE PALM,CARRIB'S PALM,SOUTH AMERICAN ROYAL PALM,KOHLPALME,WEST INDIES ROYAL PALM
memo: There are ten species of royal palms, mostly from the Caribbean. This is the second most commonly grown species in Hawaiâ€˜i, after the Cuban royal palm (<em>R. regia</em>), and both species are naturalized in several wet places on the Hawaiian Islands. <em>Roystonea oleracea</em> can be distinguished from <em>R. regia</em> by the upright leaves, which don't hang down past horizontal in this species. In its native Caribbean, the palm heart is eaten; hence its specific epithet, <em>oleracea</em>, which means edible. <em>Roystonea oleracea</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -3 (Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/roystonea-oleracea/" target="_self">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/roystonea-oleracea/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: <i>R. oleracea</i> is native to the Caribbean. Local people make an alcoholic beverage from the fermented flowers, and both the heart of palm and immature flowers can be eaten raw. Common names are â€˜royal palmâ€™ or â€˜imperial palmâ€™, and it is widely planted as an ornamental across the tropics.  (Zona, 2008)
photolocations: Foster Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI, Wahiawa Botanical Garden - Wahiawa, HI, Garden of Eden - Maui, HI and Kona and Oahu, HI

alternative_common_names: INDIAN DATE,SUGAR DATE PALM,WILD DATE PALM
memo: <strong>This plant is weedy. We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> The silver date palm is naturalized in a number of locations in Hawaiâ€˜i, but particularly on the north shore of Oahu. This species is closely related to the Canary Island date palm (<em>P. canariensis</em>), but has a more slender trunk, and fronds that are shorter and more silver in color. The two can also form hybrids.&nbsp;<em>Phoenix sylvestris</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 17 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: The â€˜sugar date palmâ€™ is native to India and Pakistan, where it is used extensively for food and medicine. The fruits and sap are used in regional traditional medicine to treat cold symptoms, fever, indigestion, and heart disease. The flowers are used to make sugars and jellies, and the fruit made into vinegar and fermented wine. (P. Jain et al., 2018)
photolocations: Oahu, HI
native_range: Southern Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, Burma and Bangladesh
flower_type: Has male and female reproductive parts in each flower (perfect)

memo: Java plum is widely naturalized in pastures, along roadsides, and wetter lowland areas throughout the Hawaiian Islands. It is rarely planted, though widely seen. It can be distinguished from other cultivated members of this massive genus (over 1,000 species) by its relatively small flowers and black fruit. <em>Syzygium cumini</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 9 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: The dark purple fruits are sweet sour, and popular to eat raw or cook into jams, sauces, juices, and deserts. This tree is considered sacred to the god Krishna, and is planted near temples throughout India and Malaysia, where it is called <i>jambolan</i>. The bark, fruit, and leaves are used in Ayurveda and Unani traditional medicines to treat diabetes, dysentery cough, infection, and inflammation. This species has naturalized in the mesic and dry lowland forests of HawaiÊ»i. (Ayyanar & Subash-Babu, 2012)
photolocations: Hilo, Maui, Kauai and Oahu, HI
native_range: India, Myanmar, Sri Lanka, Andaman Islands

alternative_common_names: `OHI`A `AI,MALAY ROSE APPLE,MALAY APPLE,ROSE APPLE,OTAHEITE APPLE,PINK SATIN-ASH,POMMERAC,OHIA AI,MACUPA,APEL EN POHNPEI,ACPUHL TAHPWENG,NONU FI'AFI'A,KIDEL,APEL,ACPUHL,ARFATH,FAARIYAP,MAKUPA
memo: Mountain apple or &lsquo;ohi a &lsquo;ai is a culturally important plant that was first introduced to the Hawaiian Islands by Polynesian settlers. The fruit can be eaten raw or cooked, the astringent bark has medicinal properties, and the fine-grained wood can be used for carving. A reddish-brown dye for making patterns on tapa bark cloth can be processed from the bark and the root.&nbsp;<em>Syzygium malaccense</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 0 (Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is:<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/syzygium-malaccense/"> https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/syzygium-malaccense/</a>
ethnobotanical_info: Mountain apple is planted by the Polynesians throughout the Pacific, and was introduced to HawaiÊ»i as a Ê»canoe plantâ€™ called <i>â€˜</i><i>ÅhiÊ»a</i><i> ai</i><i>. </i>The wood was used to construct <i>hale</i> (house dwellings) and <i>heiau</i> (sacred temples, places of worship) in pre-contact HawaiÊ»i. The tasty apple-esque fruits are eaten raw throughout the Pacific and in Indonesia the bright pink flowers are included in salads. It is planted in agroforestry systems and homegardens throughout the Pacific, Indonesia, and southeast Asia. In traditional medicine, various parts of the tree are used to treat infections, stomach pain, bronchitis, and diabetes. In <i>lÄÊ»au</i><i> </i><i>lapaÊ»au</i><i> </i>(Hawaiian traditional plant medicine), <i>â€˜</i><i>ÅhiÊ»a</i><i> ai </i>bark juice is ingested to effectively treat sore throats and throat infections. (Abbott, 1992; Whistler & Elevitch, 2006).
photolocations: Ho'omaluhia Botanical Garden - Kaneohe, HI and Kona, HI

memo: Colvilles Glory is related to the royal poinciana (<em>Delonix regia</em>) and its fern-like leaves look somewhat similar (bipinnately compound). The form of this plant is also more upright as opposed to the spreading royal poinciana. The species thrives in dry areas, and is very showy in bloom, usually in late summer to fall (one of the few trees to bloom in October in Hawaiâ€˜i). It s native to the west coast of Madagascar, where it is listed as endangered.&nbsp;<em>Colvillea racemosa</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -8 (Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/colvillea-racemosa/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/colvillea-racemosa/</a>
ethnobotanical_info: Native to Madacasgar, and planted as an ornamental for its dramatic orange inflorescence throughout the tropics.
photolocations: Foster Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI and

memo: This small to medium-sized palm is native to swamps of Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. It s grown ornamentally through the tropical world for its bright red crownshaft and leaf sheaths. The red wax used to seal documents and letters does not come from this plant, although the color of the shaft resembles it. The species requires warm temperatures and does not tolerate periods of drought.&nbsp;<em>Cyrtostachys renda</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 1.
ethnobotanical_info: An ornamental palm highly valued in landscaping for its striking scarlet crownshaft and leafsheath. Large specimens are sold for over 1,000 USD, and there are reports of targeted nursey theft of this palm. Sumatran populations of <i>C. </i><i>renda</i> are harvested by local people for thatching and construction. (Widyatmoko et al., 2005)
photolocations: Kona, Oahu, Papaikou and Maui, HI

memo: Longan is occasionally grown in Hawaiâ€˜i as a dooryard fruit tree and has been recommended for street tree planting. The fruit is produced in late summer and fall. Trees are self-fertile but bear erratically, with heavy fruit production in some years and almost none in others. They require rich soil and regular applications of fertilizer when bearing. Fruit can be used cooked or raw and the flesh of the fruit is used as an antidote for poison. The seeds can be made into shampoo and burnt for fuel.&nbsp;<em>Dimocarpus longan</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -2 (Low Risk).&nbsp;
ethnobotanical_info: Longan are related to lychee, and are celebrated for the delicate juicy sweet pulp of their fruit. Known as â€˜dragonâ€™s eyeâ€™ in Cantonese for the shiny black seed resembling an iris and pupil. Various parts of the tree are used in traditional Chinese soups, sweets, and snacks. Longan has traditional medicine applications to treat gastrointestinal disorders, anxiety, fractures, snake-bikes, and neurological disorders. Longan is grown in commercial plantations throughout China, Vietnam, and Thailand. (X. Zhang et al., 2020)
photolocations: Foster Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI and Kalaheo, Maui, HI

alternative_common_names: ELEPHANT'S EARPOD,ELEPHANT'S EAR TREE,CARO CARO,MONKEY-EAR TREE,DEVIL'S EAR,PICH,CONACASTE
memo: Large, fast-growing tree suited only for parks, large estates, open spaces. Agressive roots can list and crack infrastructure. Thrives without much care and attains impressive size. A very large specimens grow in Koloa Town, Kauai.Fruit and bark used for soap, the bark is also used for cold medicine and a gum that can be substituted for gum arabic. Seeds are toasted and eaten. Wood used for panelling, furniture and veneers. Seeds used for leis and other jewelry.&nbsp;<em>Enterolobium cyclocarpum</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 3 (Evaluate).&nbsp;
ethnobotanical_info: Its native range extends across central America, where it is culturally, medicinally, and economically valuable to Mesoamerican peoples. The large ear-shaped seeds are used to make jewelry and edible when boiled. This species is the national tree of Costa Rica, where it grows extensively in the dry forests of Guanacaste. (M et al., 2012)
photolocations: Oahu, Maui and Kauai, HI

memo: Pua kenikeni, which is used in leis, is easily grown in high-rainfall areas but must be provided with plenty of water in drier locales. It prefers full sun and a well-drained, reasonably fertile soil and requires gentle pruning to counteract its naturally straggling habit. Fruit should be picked off when young since it inhibits further flower production if allowed to develop. <em>Fagraea berteroana</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -1 (Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/fagraea-berteroana/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/fagraea-berteroana/</a>
ethnobotanical_info: The tree is native to the South Pacific and New Guinea region, but introduced to Hawaii for the lovely and distinct scent of the white flowers. The Hawaiian common name <i>p</i><i>ua</i><i> </i><i>kenikeni</i><i> </i>signifies Ê»ten cent flowerâ€™, because in the late 1800s fragrant lei of <i>pu</i><i>a</i><i> </i><i>kenikeni</i> would be sold to visitors at Honolulu harbor for ten cents. The wood is valued in Samoa and Fiji for house construction, carved handicrafts, and tools. Traditional medicinal uses include an infusion of leaves to treat internal injury, respiratory illness, and skin irritations. In Tahitian legend, <i>Fragraea</i> was brought to Tahiti from heaven by the god Tane. (Motley, 2004; Whistler, 2000)
photolocations: Hilo, Kona, Oahu, HI

alternative_common_names: MOLUCCAN ALBIZIA,KEROSIN TREE,SALAWAKU,SENGON,TAMALIGI,MOLUCCAN SAU,WHITE SIRIS,TUHKE KARSIN,UKALL RA NGEBARD,ARBASIA
memo: This is an abundant tree in the wetter areas of Kauai and Oahu. They are massive trees with brittle branches that break readily in storms, making them inappropriate for home garden planting. This species is invasive on several Hawaiian Islands as well as many other Pacific Islands where it is planted. It s grown widely as a forestry tree throughout Southeast Asia, where the soft wood is used for match-sticks, chopsticks, shipping pallets, wooden boxes, and pulp is used for paper-making.&nbsp;<em>Falcataria</em><em>&nbsp;moluccana</em>&nbsp;has a&nbsp;HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 8&nbsp;(High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: Albizia is native to Borneo and Java, where enormous trunks and soft wood are used to make boats and canoes. (Hughes et al., 2013)
photolocations: Hanalei, Kauai, Hilo, Maui, HI

memo: Fern tree is widely planted around Honolulu as a street tree, a purpose for which its nonaggressive root system and compact growth form suit it. It has a dense crown which make it an attractive shade tree. While it is easy to grow,some people appear to be allergic to fern trees in flower. The purple fruit also stains sidewalks and driveways, creating a maintenance problem. Birds also disperse the seeds into vacant lots. Its continued use as a landscape ornamental should be discouraged.It is a good candidate for a large privacy screen or windbreak. The tree is commonly cultivated in tropical and subtropical gardens and landscapes for its lush green, eye-catching foliage, compact size, uniform shape and the shade it gives.&nbsp;<em>Filicium decipiens</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 5 (Evaluate).&nbsp;
ethnobotanical_info: Native to tropical Africa and Asia, where it is occasionally used in traditional medicine to treat diabetes and bone fractures. The tree is planted ornamentally throughout tropical and subtropical regions for its attractive fern-like leaves. (Basarikatti et al., 2021)
photolocations: Fairchild Tropical Botanical Garden - Miami, FL and Oahu, Hilo, Maui, HI
flower_type: Has male and female reproductive parts in each flower (perfect)

memo: Lignum vitae, the national tree of Jamaica, is a slow-growing, often multi-stemmed small tree with the world s most dense wood. Its purple flowers are produced in late spring or summer followed by profuse orange fruit in late summer and fall. A resin derived from the wood of this tree is used medicinally.&nbsp;<em>Guaiacum</em><em>&nbsp;officinale</em>&nbsp;has a&nbsp;HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -6&nbsp;(Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is:&nbsp;<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/guaiacum-officinale/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/guaiacum-officinale/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: The Taino people of the Caribbean used the dense, dark wood of <i>Guaiacum</i> <i>officinale</i> to carve ceremonial figurines; the humanoid figures were meticulously fashioned from the heartwood, then polished with dark resin and adorned with shells. <i>Guaiacum</i> <i>officinale </i>was used for these carvings because the Taino believed the trees themselves were animated with powerful spirits. These pre-contact figurines date to the 10th century AD and are of great cultural and spiritual value. <i>G. </i><i>offi</i><i>c</i><i>i</i><i>n</i><i>ale</i> is also an important medicinal tree to the Indigenous people of the West Indies, where it is used for its anti-inflammatory properties and to induce abortion. This species is the national tree of Jamaica, where it is known as <i>lignum vitae</i>, â€˜the tree of lifeâ€™. (Ostapkowicz et al., 2011)
photolocations: Foster Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI

memo: This is an ideal beach plants, and is used in many coastal gardens. It is adapted to saline soils, salty spray, and strong prevailing winds. It is generally propagated from seed, is easy to care for, and pest free. Historically, the leaves were often used as a famine food. This plant serves as an important habitat and food source for the endangered Yellow-Faced Bee and&nbsp;creates breeding groups for some native bird species.The wood of <em>H. foertherianum</em> is commonly used to make handicrafts, tools, and, in Polynesia, frames for swim goggles.&nbsp;<em>Heliotropium foertherianum</em> has an HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 4.<br><br><a href="https://naturalhistory2.si.edu/botany/hawaiianflora/result2.cfm?genus=Tournefortia&species=argentea&rank1=&epithet1=" target="_blank">Hawaii Flora</a>
ethnobotanical_info: This salt-tolerant tree grows commonly along the coasts throughout Indo-Malaysia and the Pacific Islands. Because this tree is one of the few which grows on low Pacific atolls, it is extremely valuable in these places for animal fodder, shade, house construction, carved handicrafts, firewood, and fashioning diving goggles. An infusion of <i>Heliotropium</i> leaves is traditionally used in the Pacific to treat ciguatera fish poisoning; ethnopharmalogical research confirms that leaf extract contains high inhibitory activities against ciguatoxin. Beyond this application, <i>Heliotropium</i> is used to treat rheumatism, gout, and inflammation. The leaves are also eaten raw by people in the Maldives and Micronesia.  (Manner & Elevitch, 2006; Rossi et al., 2012)
photolocations: Kona, HI

alternative_common_names: MIRROR LEAF,LOOKING GLASS MANGROVE,SUNDARBAN MANGROVE,TULIP MANGROVE,UFA,LUUM,AKABIIBUKK,CHABIBECH,EBIBECH,MWUROPW EN SED,LUM,RUM,CHOBOCH,CHEEPWECH,ZWOBOTT,ZWOBOLT,MARAPINSET,RUNG
memo: This tree is highly adapted to life on the seashore, this species even tolerates salt water from the highest tides, if flushed by fresh water. It develops wide-spreading, shallow roots, often forming sinuous, ribbon-like, smooth-barked plank buttresses in old age. Tree is used for timber and shipbuilding. The fruit is edible.&nbsp;<em>Heritiera littoralis</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -2 (Low Risk).&nbsp;
ethnobotanical_info: A mangrove species native to east Africa and Indo-Malaysia. The durable wood is widely used for house construction, ship building, posts, and beams. In the Philippines, the sap is used as a fish poison on spearheads and known to contain toxins. The fruit of <i>H.</i> <i>littorialis</i>, called <i>dungon</i><i>, </i>is a component of the Philippine raw fish dish called <i>kinilaw</i>. (Karim et al., 2020; Miles et al., 1987)
photolocations: University of Miami - Miami- FL and Oahu, HI
flower_type: Has male and female reproductive parts in each flower (perfect)

memo: This tree tolerates salt spray and ocean breezes leading to it being planted in oceanfront gardens. It serves as a shade or street tree, and its curious waxy cupules enclosing the fruit are attractive, resembling pastel-colroed lanterns among the glossy, dark green foliage. Jack-in-the-box is readily propagated by seed and needs no special care. Wood used for tinder, some parts of the tree used medicinally. In Samoa, the fruit is strung in seed leis, and used for jewelry. Elsewhere the sap is used as a depilatory to remove body hair.&nbsp;<em>Hernandia nymphaeifolia</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -2 (Low Risk).&nbsp;
ethnobotanical_info: This coastal tree is found throughout the Pacific Islands. The leaf juice is used to chemically remove body hair. The trunk can be used to make low-quality canoes. (Thaman, 1994)
photolocations: Fairchild Tropical Botanical Garden - Miami, FL and Oahu, HI
landscape_application: Seaside Tree,Shade Tree,Coastal Street Tree,Seaside Screen
native_range: East Africa, Madagascar, throughout the tropical India and Pacific Oceans
flower_type: Has either male or female reproductive parts (dioecious)

memo: This is a slow-growing, smaller palm ideal for small yards and large pots. It is widely grown throughout Hawaiâ€˜i s coastal areas and in drier, hotter locations the foliage turns yellowish.&nbsp;<em>Hyophorbe</em><em>&nbsp;lagenicaulis</em>&nbsp;has a&nbsp;HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -3&nbsp;(Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is:&nbsp;<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/hyophorbe-lagenicaulis/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/hyophorbe-lagenicaulis/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: <i>H. </i><i>lagenicaulis</i><i> </i>is critically endangered palm endemic to a small single island off the coast of Mauritius. The population was reduced to seven individuals in 1996, thus suffered severe genetic bottlenecking, but has since marginally recovered following the eradication of goats and rabbits. Oddly enough, the species is highly popular and successful as an ornamental palm, and planted extensively across the tropics. The species represents an interesting case of ex-situ conservation, in which the wild population is severely threatened, but the species maintained through nursery collections, landscape plantings, and botanical gardens.  (Asmussen-Lange et al., 2011)
photolocations: Koko Crater Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI

memo: A small tree with a weeping habit that was planted as a street tree along University and Nuuanu Avenues in Honolulu. The root system is nonaggressive and the tree can be planted successfully in small spaces. Gum from this tree has been used as a medical healing agent, and the hard wood is sawn into decorative veneers.&nbsp;<em>Lysiphyllum</em><em>&nbsp;hookeri</em>&nbsp;has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score.
ethnobotanical_info: Native to northeastern Australia where it is called <i>pegunny</i>, and now widely cultivated as an ornamental street tree for its attractive foliage and large butterfly-esque white flowers. The tree is used in traditional medicine for its hepatoprotective and antioxidant properties. The Aboriginal people of Australia collected the treeâ€™s gum and nectar for nutritional and medicinal use. (Nicholson & Nicholson, 1992)
photolocations: Honolulu, HI

We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> Of the two widely naturalized species of&nbsp;<em>Macaranga</em>, this is the one with the larger leaves (sometimes nearly a yard across). This species and&nbsp;<em>M. tanarius</em>&nbsp;are naturalized on Oahu, Kauai, and the Big Island.&nbsp;<em>Macaranga mappa</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 11 (High Risk).

memo: <strong>This plant is weedy. We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> This species and&nbsp;<em>M. mappa</em>&nbsp;are naturalized on the windward, wet sides of Oahu, Kauai, and the Big Island. They were first introduced as horticultural plants in the early 1900s and have escaped cultivation where abundant water is available. The parasol leaf tree is also naturalized around Lhue, Kauai.&nbsp;<em>Macaranga tanarius</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 11 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: The leaves and bark are rich in tannins, which have been used to make natural dye, toughening fishing nets, preserve leather in southeast Asia. The common names for this tree in the Philippines are <i>samak</i> or <i>binunga</i>, and the leaves are used in the fermenting process of making <i>basi</i><i> </i>(local sugarcane wine). (J.-H. Lin, 1993)

alternative_common_names: INDIAN MULBERRY,CHEESE FRUIT,GREAT MORINDA,BEACH MULBERRY,LADA,WEIPWUL,SAHK II,NONU,NONU TOGIANONU,NEN,KESENGEL,LEL,NGEL,EE,MANGALWAG,LOL,ARIN,ALIN,NOPURNEN,NOPWUR,LATA,NIN
memo: <strong>This plant is weedy. We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> This large shrub or small tree has edible fruit that resembles a washed potato and has a curious, cheese-like, sometimes foul, odor. Noni is a Polynesian introduction to Hawaiâ€˜i used in many different ways. All parts of the plant have important ethnobotanical uses in Hawaiâ€˜i and elsewhere. Its bark contains a red pigment, its roots a yellow pigment, both of which are used in dying kapa (bark cloth). Noni has been marketed as a cure-all, and is cultivated as a cash crop in India and on many Pacific Islands.&nbsp;<em>Morinda citrifolia</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 10 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: <i>Noni</i> was one of the canoe plants brought by the Polynesians from Indo-Malaysia to the Pacific, reflective of its economic and medicinal importance. In HawaiÊ»i and across the Pacific, the leaves are applied to bruises and skin wounds, and a tonic made from ripe fruit is drunk to treat arthritis, indigestion, diabetes, asthma, high blood pressure, and enhance immune system health. The bark and roots yield a yellow natural dye that is used to color <i>kapa</i> (barkcloth) in HawaiÊ»i and <i>fala</i> (mats) in Samoa, and other textiles across the speciesâ€™ range. The odoriferous fruit can be eaten as a famine food. (Abbott, 1992; Wang et al., 2002)

memo: This tree produces edible products, medicine, and oil pressed from the seeds, which is used as a lamp oil and in cosmetics and perfumery. Fiber from the&nbsp;bark&nbsp;is used to make mats, cordage, and paper, and a gum that comes from the trunk is used to dye cloth. The long skinny pods resemble drumsticks, hence an occasionally used common name, drumstick tree. This species was first introduced into Hawaiâ€˜i in the mid 19th century and is now commonly grown in residential yards (especially Filipino houses) on all islands. These trees are often severely pruned to keep the height down and allow the edible leaves and fruit to be within easy reach.&nbsp;<em>Moringa oleifera</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 1 (Evaluate).
ethnobotanical_info: An extraordinarily multi-use plant, moringa is originally native to the Indian subcontinent, but is now planted throughout the global tropics and has become an indispensable part of local nutrition, medicine, and tradition. The young leaves and pods are eaten in a variety of preparations and dishes; they are very nutritious, with high levels of vitamins, minerals, antioxidants, and protein.  In Africa, the moringa leaf powder is used to fortify yam flour to make a starchy staple called <i>amala</i><i>. </i>Similarly, moringa powder can be used to add nutritional value to bread, biscuits, and cakes. In Southeast Asia, moringa seed pods are a component of traditional curries. The young leaves are a central element of the Filipino diet, where they are finely chopped and served in soups. All parts of the plant are used in traditional medicine. Moringa has been championed as Ê»the miracle plantâ€™ in developing countries because of its multiple and simultaneous benefits to agroforestry, human nutrition and health, animal forage, and water purification. (Abdull Razis et al., 2014; Oyeyinka & Oyeyinka, 2018)
photolocations: Kauai and Kona, HI

alternative_common_names: SATIN WOOD,JASMINE ORANGE,ORANGE JESSAMINE,CHINESE BOX,MOCK LIME,LAKEVIEW JASMINE
memo: The flowers of the mock orange are used for scenting teas, and almost all parts of the plant have medicinal uses. It is commonly grown as a hedge or screen, but will grow into a small tree if allowed.&nbsp;<em>Murraya paniculata</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 6 (Evaluate).
ethnobotanical_info: A common small ornamental tree planted in urban areas and neighborhoods around HawaiÊ»i. It is favored by horticulturalists for its fragrant small white flowers. <i>M. </i><i>paniculata</i> is used in herbal medicines; the dried bark and stem are used in Southeast Asia as an astringent, in China during childbirth, and in India treat malarial fever. (Olawore et al., 2005)
photolocations: Maui, Princeville, Hi, Foster Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI, Longwood Gardens - Kennette Square, PA and UC Riverside - Riverside, CA

alternative_common_names: MALABAR CHESTNUT,FRENCH PEANUT,PROVISION TREE,MONEY PLANT,SABA NUT,PUMPO,MIICH ERA NGEBARD,MIICHRANGEBARD,MONEY TREE
memo: The Guiana chestnut seed can be eaten raw or roasted. The skin of the immature green fruit is used in the treatment of hepatitis. The green bark can be made into dyes and the wood can be made into paper. Unlike other&nbsp;bombax relatives,&nbsp;Pachira blooms while leaves are still on the trees.&nbsp;<em>Pachira aquatica</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -6 (Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pachira-aquatica/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pachira-aquatica/</a>
ethnobotanical_info: The seeds are toxic when raw, but edible when roasted or boiled, with a flavor reminiscent of the true chestnut. In China and Japan, this species is a popular ornamental houseplant; saplings are sold in markets with braided stems and thought to bring good fortune to the household. (Rodrigues et al., 2019)
photolocations: University of Miami - Miami, FL and Lahaina, Maui, Oahu, HI

memo: The dried fruits of this species are used as a flavoring in a wide range of foods and an essential oil obtained from the leaves, called pimento leaf oil, is used in perfumery, especially in fragrances and after-shave lotions. It is a&nbsp;smaller, evergreen tree with whitish, mottled, peeling bark. Allspice is derived from the dried, fully grown but unripe fruit, and the foliage also is fragrant when crushed. It is called allspice because it tastes and smells like a combination of cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves.&nbsp;<em>Pimenta dioica</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 7 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: <i>P. dio</i><i>ic</i><i>a </i>is cultivated for the valuable â€˜allspiceâ€™ or â€˜pimentoâ€™, which is the ground spice produced from the treeâ€™s dried fruits. Allspice is an important element of Caribbean cuisine particularly the â€˜jerk seasoningâ€™ of Jamaica, and in traditional Mexican cooking. The fragrance of allspice is used in perfumes and cosmetic products.  <i>P. dioica</i> is a component of Caribbean folk medicine, and infusions are consumed to treat menstrual cramps, respiratory congestion, dyspepsia, and diabetes. (L. Zhang & L Lokeshwar, 2012)

memo: <strong>This plant is weedy. We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> This fast-growing tree thrives on a variety of soils in dry, sunny, leeward coasts to moist valleys and windward slopes. The wood is used for posts, rough construction, and fuel, and the bark yields gums, dyes, and tannins. The fruit pulp is eaten and used to make a beverage, as well as fodder for livestock. Several parts of the tree are used medicinally. &lsquo;Opiuma was imported to the Islands in the late 1800s and became naturalized by birds spreading the black seeds by the early 20th century. It has now invaded a number of areas on the leeward side of islands. People believed the small back seeds, which are used in leis, looked like opium, so the Hawaiian name for this tree became &lsquo;opiuma.&nbsp;<em>Pithecellobium dulce</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 14 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: This tree is native to the tropical Americas, but has naturalized extensively across the Asian and African continents. Used extensively as live fencing in Mexico, where it is called <i>guamÃºchil</i>. The seed pods contain a sweet and sour pulp similar to tamarind, and can be eaten or made into juice. The tree is used in Mexican traditional medicine to treat toothache, dysentery, and reduce fever. (Monroy & ColÃ­n, 2004; Murugesan et al., 2019)
photolocations: Kona and Oahu, HI

memo: In addition to being grown as an ornamental tree, the wavy-margined leaves of the false Ashoka are used for decoration during festivals. In India and Sri Lanka, the wood is used in the manufacturing of pencils, matchsticks, and small boxes. The oil of the seed has medicinal properties.&nbsp;<em>Monoon longifolium</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -4 (Low Risk) and the Plant Pono link is:&nbsp;<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/polyalthia-longifolia-var-pendula/" target="_self">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/polyalthia-longifolia-var-pendula/</a>
ethnobotanical_info: Native to India, where it is used in Ayurveda traditional medicine to treat uterine disorders. The wood is used to make furniture, cabinets, boxes, and boats. The species is planted as an ornamental for its unique columnar growth form. (Katkar et al., 2010)
photolocations: Foster Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI and University of Hawaii

memo: <em>Pritchardia</em>&nbsp;is a genus of about 30 species of fan palms, native to the Pacific Islands, with two-thirds of the species being endemic to the Hawaiian Islands. This was also the only genus of palms growing in Hawaiâ€˜i before human arrival, and pollen records indicate that they dominated dry lowland forests in some areas. This slow-growing palm, native to Fiji, grows well in full sun, moist, well-drained soil, and is relatively wind tolerant. It does best in alkaline soil as it grows on limestone soils in its native range. It can be distinguished from&nbsp;<em>P. pacifica</em>&nbsp;by the fact that the inflorescence hangs below the foliage.&nbsp;<em>Pritchardia thurstonii</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -4 (Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is:&nbsp;<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pritchardia-thurstonii/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pritchardia-thurstonii/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: This species of <i>Pritchardia</i> is native to Tonga, and has been introduced by early Polynesians to Fiji, HawaiÊ»i, Samoa, and the Marquesas Islands. It is widely grown as an ornamental palm throughout the Pacific. The broad fronds were traditionally used as <i>ai </i><i>viu</i> (fans) for local chiefs. (Bacon et al., 2012)
photolocations: Hilo, Kona and Wahiawa Botanical Garde - Wahiawa, HI

This was also the only genus of palms growing in Hawaiâ€˜i before human arrival, and pollen records indicate that they dominated dry lowland forests in some areas. This slow growing palm, native to Fiji, grows well in full sun, moist, well-drained soil, and is relatively wind tolerant. It does best in alkaline soil as it grows on limestone soils in its native range. It can be distinguished from <em>P. pacifica</em> by the fact that the inflorescence hangs below the foliage. <em>Pritchardia thurstonii</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -4 (Low Risk), and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://pla">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pritchardia-thurstonii/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: This species of <i>Pritchardia</i> is native to Fiji, and is now planted ornamentally throughout the Pacific.<i> </i><i>P. </i><i>thurstonii</i> has been observed planted near Fijian burial caves, and an infusion made from the crushed stem is drank to protect oneself from death spirits. (Bacon et al., 2012)

alternative_common_names: LOULU,LOULU PALM,HAWAII PRITCHARDIA,KONA FAN PALM,MAIDEN'S LOULU,KONA LOULU
memo: <em>Pritchardia</em>&nbsp;is a genus of about 30 species of fan palms, native to the Pacific Islands, with two-thirds of the species being endemic to the Hawaiian Islands. This was also the only genus of palms growing in Hawaiâ€˜i before human arrival, and pollen records indicate that they dominated dry lowland forests in some areas. The hard wood of the trunk of taller species of loulu was fashioned into spears by early Hawaiians, and the fruit can be eaten. This species is found natively in Fiji and Tonga.&nbsp;<em>Pritchardia maideniana</em>&nbsp;has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score.
ethnobotanical_info: The â€˜Kona palmâ€™ is a species of <i>Pritchardia</i> only found on the south side of HawaiÊ»i Island where Hawaiian people cultivated them. <i>P. </i><i>maideniana</i> is listed as a critically endangered species, with only ~70 individuals remaining in the wild. (Chapin et al., 2004)

memo: <em>Pritchardia</em>&nbsp;is a genus of about 30 species of fan palms, native to the Pacific Islands, with two-thirds of the species being endemic to the Hawaiian Islands. This was also the only genus of palms growing in Hawaiâ€˜i before human arrival, and pollen records indicate that they dominated dry lowland forests in some areas. Native to Molokai,&nbsp;<em>Pritchardia hillebrandii</em>&nbsp;is the most commonly grown endemic&nbsp;<em>Pritchardia</em>&nbsp;in Hawaiâ€˜i. The leaves are often bluish gray-green with whitish wool on the undersides.&nbsp;<em>Pritchardia hillebrandii</em>&nbsp;has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score and the Plant Pono link is:&nbsp;<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pritchardia-hillebrandii/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pritchardia-hillebrandii/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: <i>Pritchardia</i><i> </i><i>hillebrandii</i> is an endangered species of palm endemic to HawaiÊ»i; the population has been reduced to the small islets of Mokapu and Huelo, offshore of MolokaÊ»i. <i>P. </i><i>hillebrandii</i> is well represented in ex-situ collections, with numerous plantings in botanical gardens, restoration sites, private homes, and landscaping across the islands. It is believed that the small Huelo population is a relic forest spared from rat seed predation; paleo-botanical research has shown that prior to the introduction of Polynesian rats (<i>Rattus </i><i>exulans</i>), <i>loulu</i> forest was extensive across the coastal lowlands of HawaiÊ»i. <i>Loulu</i> leaves were used in the ritual construction of <i>heiau </i><i>mÄpele</i> (seasonal fishing shrines) and are used today to thatch <i>hale</i> (traditional Hawaiian houses). (Shiels & Drake, 2015; Wood, 2010)
photolocations: Oahu, HI

memo: This species has a swollen grayish-green trunk and palmately compound leaves. In the spring, they become deciduous before going into flower. The large flowers can be rose-pink or white with colored stamen and thin petals that recurve as the flowers open. Flowers fall and carpet the ground while the tree continues to bloom for weeks. Both pinkish-red and white flower forms are grown in Hawaiâ€˜i and California. The cotton-like fibers surrounding the seeds are used for stuffing cushions and pillows.&nbsp;<em>Pseudobombax ellipticum</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -2 (Low Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: Locally called <i>amapolla</i><i> </i>or <i>chulte</i>, <i>Pseudobombax</i><i> </i><i>ellipticum</i><i> </i>is native to present day Mexico and Guatemala, where it is considered a sacred tree by the Mayan people. In Mesoamerica, the sap and flowers were fermented to make an intoxicating drink used in religious ceremony. Representations of the unique flowers are frequently depicted on Mayan ceramics dating to approximately 300-900 AD. A tea of <i>P. </i><i>ellipticum</i> is used by Nahua women in Veracruz to induce sterility in old age. These beautiful deciduous trees are planted ornamentally across the tropics. (Smith-Oka, 2008; Zidar & Elisens, 2009)
photolocations: University of Miami - Miami, FL, Fairchild Tropical Botanical Garden - Miami, FL, Foster Botanical Garden - Honolulu, HI, Waimea Valley Oahu and Maui, HI
native_range: Southern Mexico to Central America and Cuba

memo: This small tree or large shrub is a Hawaiian native with glossy, dark green leaves and fragrant white flowers. The coffee-like, 2-celled drupe fruits turn black when ripe. It prefers dry conditions but can tolerate moistness if the soil is well-drained. It grows well in full sun and in dryer areas with well-drained soil. A black dye was made from the leaves and the hard wood is used for spears, wooden tools, lei making, and medicinal purposes. <em>Psydrax odorata</em> has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score, and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/psydrax-odorata/" target="_self">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/psydrax-odorata/</a>.

pest_susceptibility: Green Coffee Scale (Coccus viridis),Black Twig Borer (Xylosandrus comapctus)

alternative_common_names: BLOODWOOD,BURMESE ROSEWOOD,AMBOYNA WOOD,MALAY PADAUK,PAPUA NEW GUINEA ROSEWOOD,PHILIPPINE MAHOGANY,ANDAMAN REDWOOD,NAR,NARA,LAS
memo: A popular flowering shade tree and street tree also planted for reforestation in several forest reserves. Narra is a graceful tree with drooping branches that toss in the trade winds. Short-lived flowers usually appear in April or May, and for a day or two the tree is a shimmering mass of fragrant yellow blooms, which then fall off nearly all at once. The curious winged fruit stays on the tree for months. It requires no special care, average garden soil, and ample water until it establishes. Native from Burma to the western Pacific Islands, it is the national tree of the Philippines. Also known as bloodwood and rosewood, it is a valuable timber for furniture making. Its yellow pea-like flowers are followed by flattened one-seeded fruits with a wing-like edge. Timber used for furniture. <em>Pterocarpus indicus</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 4 (Evaluate), and the Plant Pono link is:<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pterocarpus-indicus/"> https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/pterocarpus-indicus/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: <i>P. indicus</i> is the national tree of the Philippines, where it is called the <i>narra</i><i> </i>or <i>asana.</i><i> </i><i>Narra</i> is considered one of Asia-Pacificâ€™s finest timbers; the wood is deeply colored, fragrant, durable in saltwater, termite-resistant, and used to construct furniture, boats, musical instruments, handicrafts, flooring, and high-quality tools. Bark extracts are used in traditional medicine to treat digestive problems and skin infection. Herbal medicinal teas and pills of <i>narra</i> extract are sold commercially in the Philippines. <i>Narra</i> populations have been depleted or extinguished in some parts of the distribution due to overharvest. (Thomson, 2006)
photolocations: Kona, HI and Foster Botanical Gardens - Honolulu, HI

memo: This Madagascar native palm is a popular houseplant grown for its bright green, arching fronds. Different plants are either male or female (dioecious) and the frond bases are densely wooly. <em>Ravenea rivularis</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -3 (Low Risk) and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/ravenea-rivularis/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/ravenea-rivularis/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: This species of palm is native to central Madagascar, where its population is considered vulnerable due to deforestation and habitat loss. The palm heart of <i>R. </i><i>rivularis</i> is eaten by local people, and the fronds are woven into hats, mats, and baskets. It is widely grown as an indoor and outdoor ornamental throughout the world. (Latif, 2020)
photolocations: Lyon Arboretum - Honolulu, HI, Los Angeles, CA and Cal Poly Campus - San Luis Obispo, CA

memo: Monkeypod is one of the most commonly grown ornamental trees on the Hawaiian Islands. This tree is native to Central America and now grown throughout the tropics for roadside shade and wood for turning bowls and carving. The seeds are strung in leis, and in Central America, the pods are fed to cattle. The fruit pulp is sweet and edible.&nbsp;<em>Samanea saman</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 4 (Evaluate), and the Plant Pono link is:&nbsp;<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/samanea-saman/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/samanea-saman/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: These elegant trees are originally native to Central and South America, and have naturalized extensively across the Pacific. The leaves exhibit foliar Ê»nyctinastic movementâ€™, which means they fold close during the night or during rain. This phenomenon might be origin of the common name, â€˜rain treeâ€™. The extraordinarily sticky pods are edible and taste like licorice. In South America, <i>S. saman</i> is planted in agroforestry and silvopastoral systems to shade crops and provide nutritious forage for ruminants.  The bark is used in folk medicine to treat constipation, a tincture from the leaves treats diarrhea, and the seeds are chewed to ease a sore throat. <i>Samanea</i><i> saman</i> was introduced to HawaiÊ»i in 1847, and has since become a beloved shade tree planted along streets, urban parks, schools, and beaches. The wood is attractively colored, and used around the world to make furniture, boats, houses, boxes, and handicrafts. The â€˜monkey pod bowlsâ€™ of HawaiÊ»i are particularly popular as tourist souvenirs and local commemorative trophy bowls. (Durr, 2001; Little, 1989; Staples & Elevitch, 2006)
photolocations: Moanalua Gardens - Honolulu, HI, Kona, Maui and Hilo, HI

alternative_common_names: STINKY STERCULIA,HAZEL STERCULIA,JAVA OLIVE TREE,WILD ALMOND TREE,BANGAR,KALUMPANG
memo: This tree s flowers, which appear in winter and spring shortly after the new leaves, have an unmistakable odor of bad breath and rotting meat. The seeds are eaten raw, which may be toxic, or roasted, which eliminated any poison. The seed oil is used as a lubricant, and the seeds are used in lei making.&nbsp;<em>Sterculia foetida</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 3 (Evaluate).
ethnobotanical_info: <i>Sterculia </i><i>foetida</i> is a stately deciduous tree with a large native distribution across Eastern Africa, India, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The flowers have a strong offensive odor of rotting meat. In Vietnam, the crystalized sap of <i>S. </i><i>foetida</i> is used to make a popular sweet beverage called <i>má»§</i><i> </i><i>trÃ´m</i><i>.</i><i> </i>The seeds can be eaten when roasted, but are carcinogenic when raw. The bark, leaves, and roots are used in traditional medicine to treat a variety of maladies, and as a natural insect repellent. The oil made from the seeds of <i>S. </i><i>foetida</i> has high potential in biofuel production. (Mujumdar et al., 2000; Silitonga et al., 2013)
photolocations: Cal Poly State University - San Luis Obispo, CA, University of Miami - Miami, FL and Honolulu, HI

alternative_common_names: BURMESE TEAK,CENTRAL PROVINCE TEAK,NAGPUR TEAK,BANGKOK TEAK,SAK PACLANG,TSIK,TUHKEHN WAI,TIK
memo: Teak is a large tree, widely grown and harvested for timber in tropical areas worldwide, and occasionally grown in Hawaiâ€˜i on school campuses, in parks, churchyards, and large estates. In its native range in India, Myanmar, Thailand, and Malaysia, teak has been heavily clear-cut. The wood, which resists rot, has many uses including building, plywood, and outdoor furniture. Many medicinal uses have been recorded for different parts, including leaves, seeds and bark, of the tree. <em>Tectona grandis</em> has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -5 (Low Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: Arguably the most valuable tropical timber species, <i>Tectonia</i><i> grandis </i>wood<i> </i>is prized around the world for its durability, attractive coloration, high natural oil content, resistance to fungi and rot, workability, and termite resistance. The native distribution of teak is restricted to India, Burma, Thailand, and Laos, but the species is now commercially planted throughout the tropics for timber. Almost every part of the tree is used in traditional medicine to treat diabetes, leprosy, skin infection, inflammation, hemorrhage, and childbirth pain. Because of the high value placed on teak,  control over and profits from teak plantations have been historically implicated in colonial policies, environmental injustice, and human rights violations throughout Africa and Indonesia. (Kaosa-ard, 1981; Vyas et al., 2019)
photolocations: Foster Botanical Gardens - Honolulu, HI and Maui, HI
flower_type: Has male and female reproductive parts in each flower (perfect)

alternative_common_names: PORTIA TREE,PACIFIC ROSEWOOD,ADEN APPLE,INDIAN TULIP TREE,SEASIDE MAHOE,BADRIRT,BANALO,BANG-BENG,KILULO,MIO,MIRO,MULOMULO,PAHNUH,BANALU,KILUK,KILULU,KULUK,QUILULU,BADERIRT,PONE,PAKEENA,BANGBENGBANGBENG,PONO,PONA,LIKOKON,LOLO,PENE,AMAE,PANU,OKURAN
memo: Milo is a culturally important tree likely introduced to the Hawaiian Islands by Polynesian settlers. It can be recognized by its glossy, heart-shaped leaves, yellow, dark-throated hibiscus-like flowers, and woody, brown fruit in the shape of compressed globes. They grow well in low-lying, coastal areas with fruit that float and seeds that germinate on the beach. For this reason, this species is now widely naturalized in tropical coastal areas across the world. The fine-grained wood is valued for carving, and the bark yields tough fibers used for cordage, fishing lines, and coffee bags. Hau (<em>Hibiscus tiliaceus</em>) is an indigenous related member of the cotton family (Malvaceae) with fruit that split open at maturity and leaves lacking the long tips of milo.&nbsp;<em>Thespesia populnea</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 9 (High Risk), and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/thespesia-populnea/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/thespesia-populnea/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: Milo is an extremely important tree to Pacific Island communities. It was transported across the Pacific by Polynesian voyagers, is planted as an integral component of coastal agroforests. Milo is a favorite wood for carving the â€˜<i>umeke</i> (calabash containers) of HawaiÊ»i, and occasionally to make <i>waÊ»a</i> (oceangoing outrigger canoes) and smaller coastal vessels. The bark is soaked in water and braided to make cordage, although inferior quality than the cordage made from <i>hau</i> (<i>Hibiscus tiliaceus</i>) or <i>wauke</i> (<i>Broussonetia</i><i> </i><i>papyrifera</i><i>). </i>Thespesia populnes is considered a sacred tree in Tahiti, where it is planted around temples and used it ritual adornment. In the <i>kumulipo</i> (Hawaiian creation chant), the milo tree is born from <i>pÅ</i> (darkness, the first night) along with the eel and other culturally important plants and animals. (Abbott, 1992; Friday & Okano, 2006c)
photolocations: Moanalua Gardens - Honolulu, HI, Lyon Arboretum - Honolulu, HI and Hilo, HI

It has since become widely cultivated in warm, dry areas worldwide.&nbsp;<em>Wodyetia bifurcata</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 0 (High Risk), and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/wodyetia-bifurcata/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/wodyetia-bifurcata/</a>.
ethnobotanical_info: This graceful palm is endemic to northeastern Australia, where it is considered a threatened species due to overharvest.

memo: Coast banksia is a large shrub to small tree with toothed leaves with silvery undersides. Yellow flowers and brown woody fruit are born in cone-like structures that set most often in fall. This species has a basal burl, an adaptation for quick recovery after fire, so it can be pruned hard to the burl to regenerate the plant.

memo: Western juniper is a tree of open woodlands, widely distributed in the western United States from southern Washington and western Idaho to northeastern California. Juniperus occidentalis grows farther to the north than its close relative Juniperus grandisamp;(SIERRA JUNIPER). Juniperus occidentalis dominates the Northern Juniper Woodland on the Modoc Plateau. It continues northward on similar relatively low-elevation, volcanic habitats. It s also scattered westward across the Cascades. Juniperus grandis occursamp;in higher-elevation habitats, at times approaching 11,000 feet. Along the Sierra Nevada, Sierra Juniper is often associated with Jeffrey pine and other subalpine trees on dry, exposed ridges. The northern limit is near Susanville. Trees north of that are Juniperusamp;occidentalis. See Giffin and Critchfield, The Distribution of Forest Trees in California, 1972 for more information.

We do not recommend planting it in Hawaiâ€˜i. </strong><br> This species is highly naturalized around Hilo on&nbsp;the Big Island where it was planted in a 1920s reforestation program. Its a fast growing large shrub or small tree with heart shaped, hairy leaves. Its&nbsp;native to India, Southeast Asia, and northwestern Australia and New Guinea.&nbsp;It is widely cultivated as a shade tree for timber seedlings and coffe plantations, as well as for cow fodder.&nbsp;<em>Melochia unbellata</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of 9 (High Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: A pioneer tree is disturbed sites, <i>Melochia</i><i> </i><i>umbellat</i><i>a</i> is a fast-growing shrub that has become invasive in Hawaiâ€™i after an aerial seeding effort in 1925. The species is planted in agroforestry and shade-plantations throughout the tropics. (Little, 1989)

memo: False olive is regularly planted as a street tree on Oahu and occasionally as a shade tree on other Pacific Islands. Juvenile leaves (often found sprouting at the trunk base) differ significantly from the opposite, oval-shaped, slightly toothed mature leaves of the canopy. The narrow, spear-shaped juvenile leaves have red veins and margins, making them attractive for container and foliage plants.&nbsp;In traditional medicine, the plant has been used to treat high blood pressure, hypertension dysentery and gonorrhea.&nbsp;<em>Elaeodendron orientale</em>&nbsp;has a HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score of -1 (Low Risk).
ethnobotanical_info: The timber has extensively been harvested in the Renunion and Mauritius islands for its valuable red hardwood. The fruit resembles olives, but they are inedible. Used by Mauritian people to treat hypertension. (Neergheen et al., n.d.)

The Plant Pono link for Baobab is&nbsp;<a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/adansonia-digitata/">https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/adansonia-digitata/</a>&nbsp;

There are six species of Thuja, with two in North America, one of which grows in California. The western red cedar is the largest. It grows on moist slopes and deep gulches from Humboldt County north to Alaska; inland, it occurs in the northern Rockies from northern Idaho and western Montana into Alberta and British Columbia. Though it reaches its southern limit in California, this species forms extensive stands of massive trees along the Oregon and Washington coasts. Tapered trunks, often with buttressed bases, covered in cinnamon bark, support drooping limbs of aromatic foliage. Branchlets with tightly overlapping, paired, scale-like leaves are born in flat sprays. Small, egg-shaped, few-seeded cones cluster upright on the branchlets.
This is a smaller, dwarfed variety, cultivar of Dutch Elm. Leaves turn orange in fall. Smog tolerant. Susceptible to Dutch Elm Disease.

memo: <span style="color: rgb(33,37,41);background-color: rgb(255,255,255);font-size: 16px;">This small mallee shrub is grown all throughout the world, planted for it's small blule-green juvenile leaves. To maintain these attractive young leaves, the shrub needs to be trimmed back every few years to maintain its short stature. If left alone, it will grow into a dense spreading malle with green olive foliage. </span><br><br><a href="https://know.ourplants.org/" target="_self"><span style="color: rgb(69,117,55);background-color: transparent;font-size: 16px;">From Dean Nicolle and Malcolm French</span></a><span style="color: rgb(33,37,41);background-color: rgb(255,255,255);font-size: 16px;">: The epithet is from the Latin luna tus (bent into a crescent), alluding to its commonly known trade name of E. â€˜Moon Lagoonâ€™. The name â€˜Moon Lagoonâ€™ was first coined by Peter Luscombe in the early 1990s, when he owned and managed the Australian native seed service Nindethana. Luscombe, recognising the potential of the species for cut foliage, collected commercial quantities of seed of the species from his property called â€˜Moon Lagoonâ€™, adjacent to Lake Chinocup Reserve just west of Pingrup. The property was partly named for its crescent-shaped saltpans and small salt lakes, but especially for a defining event in Luscombeâ€™s life: â€œcamping with my two young daughters and walking across one of the salt crystal lakes with about 1 cm of water in it, with moon and stars above and below, gave the impression of walking in space â€“ theyâ€™ve never forgotten after 30 yearsâ€ (Peter Luscombe, pers. comm.).</span>

memo: Koai'a is a short tree adapted to the dry habitats on the Hawiian islands. The wood of Koai'a was used to make a variety of tools, and is denser and harder than the wood of Koa. Some people consider Koai'a and Koa as the same species. The young leaves are feathery and divided but quickly develop into single, curved, leathery simple leaves (called phyllodes). Many acacias, especially the species native to Australia and the Pacific Islands make leaves that mature into simple, undivided phyllodes. This is thought to be a drought adaptation. <em>Acacia koaia</em> has no HPWRA (Hawaiâ€˜i Pacific Weed Risk Assessment) score, and the Plant Pono link is: <a href="https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/acacia-koa/" target="_blank"> https://plantpono.org/pono-plants/acacia-koaia/</a>

memo: Senegalia greggii, native to arid regions of North America, is a shrub with distinct features. Its leaves are typically small, with multiple pairs of tiny, delicate leaflets, giving it a finely textured appearance. During its flowering season, it produces small, spherical clusters of pale yellow to cream-colored blossoms. While these flowers are not particularly showy, they are essential for pollinators and support local ecological interactions. The plant's fruits are relatively inconspicuous, resembling small pods, and serve as a means of reproduction. Senegalia greggii is well-adapted to the challenging conditions of arid landscapes, where it provides habitat and sustenance for various desert wildlife, making it a valuable component of the native flora.

memo: The Happy Tree is a large deciduous tree found in forest margins and streams in low elevation parts of China. One of it's common names, cancer tree, comes from the fact that it produces compounds that have been shown to be effective in treating cancer. Leaves are shaped with a pointed tip, and its small, greenish flowers appear in clusters. The tree is noted for its significance in traditional medicine, as its bark and leaves contain compounds with potential anti-cancer properties. Additionally, Camptotheca acuminata produces small, round fruits. It is sometimes cultivated for its timber, although it is not as common as its medicinal applications. This tree's intriguing attributes make it an interesting subject for horticulturists and those interested in traditional herbal remedies.

memo: One of two members of the Legume Family that is native to the Juan FernÃƒÂ¡ndez archipelago, off the west coast of Chile. It is endemic to the island chain, and rare in the wild.
photolocations: Valparaiso, Chile

memo: Bosnian Pine is a two-needled pine native to the mountains of Bosnian peninsula and southern Italy. It is a common horticultural tree throughout Europe. It's good reforestry tree, and is more pest-resistant than other pine species it co-occurs with.
photolocations: Misouri Botanical garden - St. Louis, MO and Albuquerque, New Mexico

memo: Compton Oak is a deciduous hybrid oak that is a cross between gt;Q. lyrata gt;Q. virginiana. gt;Leaf fall is variable between individual hybrids in both color and timing.

An evergreen oak native to the western Mediterranean. It often hybridizes with, and is sometimes treated as the same species, as gt;Quercus ilexgt;. Records of their acorns being used by humans of the Iberian Peninsula date back 9,000 years. The acorns can be toasted and ground into a mush, like in many oak species.
photolocations: San Luis Obispo, Califorina

memo: Tucker's Oak is endemic to chaparral and oak woodlands in California. It is most typically a medium to large shrub, growing to a maximum 20 feet tall. This oak grows on dry slopes, and would likely make a good, drought-tolerant, landscape shrub.
photolocations: San Luis Obispo, California

memo: Muller oak grows in pinyon-juniper woodlands and desert margins of Southern California. This shrub rarely exceeds 10 feet tall, and can be easily distinguished from California's other shrub oaks by its bifacialed leaves.
photolocations: Joshua Tree National Park, California

memo: A small flowering tree native to the islands and gt;Archipelagosgt; in the Phillipine Sea and Queensland, Australia. It is widely cultivated for its essential oils used in perfumes. Ylang-ylang has been introduced to the Pacific Islands, Africa and the Americas. While in the wild it can grow up to 100 feet tall, in cultivation it is often much shorter.
photolocations: Balboa Park, San Diego, California

memo: A deciduous shrub native to most of North America. It is never the dominant shrub in forests, but just making up an occassional part of the understory. Like other members of this genus, it has been used for hundreds of years as food and medicine for Native Americans.
photolocations: Santa Cruz Country, California

memo: A fast growing acaia with a weeping habit that is relatively drought tolerant. It has beautiful blue folia, cream colored flowers, and interesting leaves.
photolocations: San Luis Obispo, California
invasive_text: An escaped ornamental in many parts of Australia just outside of it's native range.

memo: quot;color: rgb(33,37,41);background-color: rgb(255,255,255);font-size: 16px;gt;Belloto del Sur is rare and nearly extinct in the wild, now only found in the foothills of the Andesgt;. It can be commonly confused with a closely related species, gt;Beilseschmiedia gt;miersiigt;, but gt;B. berteroanagt; has smaller fruit and leaves. It is planted widely throughout Chile and occasionally in Europe.

memo: This is a rare species, restricted to ~700 individuals in its native range southeastern Australia.

memo: This is a widely planted ornamental tree in southern Australia, as it grows and flowers quickly.
